newsitem.title: USA: Zebra sees sustainable gross margins.
newsitem.headline: Zebra sees sustainable gross margins.

text.p: Zebra Technologies Inc said Friday it expected its gross margins to hold steady after reaching its highest in two years during the third quarter.

Late Thursday, the company reported better-than-expected third-quarter earnings of $0.36 a share on sales of $43.8 million, compared with EPS of $0.04 and $37.5 million in sales in the third quarter of 1995.
Zebra, which supplies bar code technology, reported a gross margin of 49 percent for the most recent quarter.
"I think it is sustainable...assuming there are no huge changes in price levels in the industry," said Randy Whitchurch, Zebra's chief financial officer.
"I'm not going to tell you to expect them (gross margins) to continue to go upward, but I wouldn't tell you to take them down either," he said in a conference call with analysts.
In second quarter, the company said its gross margin was 47.9 percent. The last time it reached 49 percent was in the fourth quarter of 1994, Whitchurch said.
He said the rise reflected increased software sales, products with higher prices and expanded levels of operations.
"This is a very solid gross margin figure with no funny money," Whitchurch said.
Zebra said it cut spending as a result of disappointing results in the first half of the year. The company said the spending changes would not hurt key product development.

"The net effect of our sales growth, gross margin expansion and reduction of operating spending was an increase in operating margins to 27.3 percent and a new record in the level of operating profits," said Ed Kaplan, chairman and chief executive officer of Zebra, in the conference call. "This
gets back to the traditional levels we saw last year."
Shares of Zebra were trading up 2-3/16 to 28 at 1320 EDT/1720 GMT Friday.
